Subject: Re: [junit] Why no errors in JUnit 4?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=12653864; y=HW760C5Uf5h93vA6FtU7SqGzrXTbIr2FFgdtYanTS7YcXnwH

David Saff wrote:
> That's interesting.  I myself never really found it all that useful, nor 
> that much of a distraction.  What did you use it for?  Did you fix 
> errors before failures, or vice versa?  Did you find one harder to fix 
> than the other?
> 

It's simply useful that Eclipse tells me which are which. Errors 
normally point me toward unexpected couplings and dependencies whereas 
failures tend not to. With an error my reaction is normally, "Why the 
hell did *that* break?" whereas with a failure, I normally have a pretty 
good idea why the piece that broke is the piece that broke. Sometimes an 
error indicates something that wasn't tested as well as it should have 
been, and shows me that I need to add another test case to cover it.

Since I rarely get very far before running the test suite, it's rare 
that I have multiple unrelated errors and failures. However, sometimes 
one change does cause both, and I normally do look at the errors first. 
They seem to more reliably point me at the bug.

--
